title: Future Returns: Investing to Drive Climate Action
text:
Text size

The effect climate change is having on the planet is apparent in melting glaciers, persistent droughts, and fiercer storms.

These physical manifestations are becoming more clear, but what’s less obvious is how climate change could wreak havoc on up to 17% of global financial assets, the U.S. investment management firm Cornerstone Capital Group concluded in a research report published earlier this month.

The risks to assets from climate change are so pervasive that “unless investment dollars are deployed at scale to limit further warming—there’s no place to hide,” the report said.

One reason are so-called feedback loops that exist between the financial system and the macroeconomy. If a house that serves as collateral for a home-equity loan is destroyed in a hurricane, banks will be less likely to lend in that community, and that means consumers will have less money to spend, the report said.

To devise an estimated dollar figure for this impact, Cornerstone Capital synthesizes climate change research from the Economist Intelligence Unit, the London School of Economics, and the UNEP Finance Initiative, to conclude that US$3 trillion to US$24 trillion in global financial financial assets are at risk.

While investors may not be able to hide from these risks, there’s much they can do to mitigate the effects of climate change, and lesson the harm to financial assets.

“Literally, everyday it gets easier to create a diversified climate-aware or climate-targeted portfolio for any size investor, from small to large,” says Craig Metrick, managing institutional consulting and research at Cornerstone.

Metrick spoke with Penta about how individuals can invest to address climate change, drawing from a separate report the firm also published this month.

Access to Investments

Investing solely in renewable energy companies or electric vehicle makers would be a valid approach for investors who want to take action on climate. But Metrick says not every investor will want a portfolio of only clean tech or renewable energy investments.

Instead, Cornerstone suggests taking action on climate through a series of “access themes,” that are part of a framework the firm developed to help clients find investments that align with the various sustainable development goals (SDGs) identified by the United Nations in 2015. “Climate Action” is SDG No. 13.

What the access themes do is make the SDGs “more investor- and investment-friendly,” Metrick says. “It allows us to better capture the intersectionality of some of these issues.”

Access to sustainable sources of food and nutrition, for example, “is not just important for nutrition and human health, it’s also better for the climate,” he says.

These themes, including “access to education,” or “access to clean air,” “allow clients to take a more holistic approach to their investments and maybe create a more diversified portfolio,” Metrick says. But the approach “still gets to the issues and impacts that they are looking for.”

Beyond Solar Energy

One example Metrick gives is a venture-capital fund the firm is in the process of recommending to its clients that doesn’t bill itself as a climate solutions fund, but the themes it is investing in—the environment, education, and mobility—will drive climate action.

“If you put those [themes] together, you really get a sense for things that can improve life in urban areas, and if you look at some of the solutions that they are targeting, they could have a tremendous impact on more sustainable communities as well as a huge impact on resource use,” Metrick says.

Education is critical because “you need an educated population to understand the science and to have the knowledge and the economic wherewithal to seek solutions,” he says.

One of this fund’s investments offers online learning and support for working mothers to get additional education for their children.

“It’s not a direct link to reducing emissions, but over time, we do think a greater level of education in the developing world, and for women, can improve the way people understand and interact with their environment,” Metrick says.

They are also investing in solutions to reduce food waste, such as a companies that can make use of food that is past its peak food date. “Reducing food waste is a huge one for the climate,” Metrick adds.

Stocks, Bonds, Alternatives

Cornerstone also details how investors can select investments among stocks, bonds, or alternatives, to achieve action on climate—in other words, it’s possible to create a diversified climate action portfolio.

A client could invest in an equity real-estate investment trust (REIT), for example, that invests in companies providing farmer-friendly leases and mortgages to organic farmers. For bonds, investors can choose funds investing in companies emphasizing energy efficiency, renewables, mass transit, and carbon capture, for example, or a fund that provides financing to solar projects.

Alternative investments, including real estate, private equity, and venture capital, can often allow investors to make a more direct impact, such as a real assets fund “that buys farmland in the U.S. in regions near markets with strong demand for locally grown, organic food,” or a private-equity fund focused on climate infrastructure projects.

Some of the strategies Cornerstone describes are new or emerging, but there’s no doubt, Metrick says, that the landscape of potential investments, both public and private, is changing constantly.

“You name it, it’s coming,” he says.

To Metrick, it’s important for clients to consider some of the newer approaches, too, “because without that we’re not going to get the impact we need,” he says. “Not every client wants to shoulder the risk of a brand-new strategy, but we don’t want to dismiss things solely because they don’t have a three-year track record or a US$100 million portfolio.”
description: Cornerstone Capital’s Craig Metrick on how to align a diversified portfolio to stem climate change
